title: My ex-wife had a Verizon Wireless account set-up at our apartment that had hi-speed internet and phone. The account was set-up
question: before we were married and only in her name. At the date of Seperation, (we just finished our divorce), she contacted Verizon Wireless and said she would be leaving the apartment and had the Merchant Vendor transfer her account into my name solely. This was done without my knowledge or permission/authorization. I checked my credit report and there was a credit inquiry that hit my credit reports. She provided my social security card numbers and had them authorize a credit check before transferring service into my name. I spent days with Verizon to remove or transfer back to no avail. It is now in collections and is impacting my credit negatively with a balance. What legal actions could I take to resolve? I filed a report with LAPD Fraud dept, but their detectives are overloaded.
answers:
Send a certified letter to the Collection Agency telling them that you are not responsible and that they should stop hassling you or engaging in unfair debt collection practices. If they don't stop contact an Attorney who specializes in suing debt collectors.
In San Jose you may want to contact Fred Schwinn at the link provided below

This sounds as though it is an issue you should be able to resolve with Verizon.

It may be best to file a small claims case against your former spouse to get a judgment against her for what you have had to pay.

BW
